Another reason is to do with the math in packet and piece transfer in the swarm, the whole file is broken down into smaller chunks prior to being hashed.

This creates more packets to be distributed and actually speeds up the swarm on cascade.

Or you can select "Extract here" from the right click menu but cut and paste out to somewhere else as sometimes this can make client read extra data and fail the hashcheck for the torrent.

DeltaPan, rar torrents are retarded.  This has nothing to do with torrent protocols, packet sizes, or transmission efficiency, and I've never seen anyone try to argue those points.  It's a simple matter of practicality.

For a torrent like this, which is a couple-day-old episode of an uber-popular TV show and a smallish file, the problems with RAR aren't quite as obvious.  We have thousands of people in the swarm.

It's a lot more obvious when you're dealing with less popular torrents.  People don't seed RAR files for very long, because it requires them to store the information twice -- once in the RAR file, and once in a usable format.

There's nothing worse than downloading an 18 GB torrent that stores "the entire series" of some obscure TV show and has 1 seeder.  In all likelihood, I won't get the entire torrent, and because it's RAR, I'm virtually guaranteed not to get a single episode.  Worse yet, I'm at a moral conundrum if I successfully download it.  I now have to decide whether I am willing to expend 18 GB of disk space to save the series (answer: yes) and ANOTHER 18 GB of disk space to help seed it for other people (answer:  uh... crap!).

At 2.5 TB of media, I have hundreds of torrents that are usable as-is and stay in my queue for months, sometimes seeding to ratios of 40 or 50. I try to respect the uploaders and always go to 100%, but RAR torrents don't get more than that from me.  I hate doubling my disk usage because some weenie had a retarded moment.  Casual observation suggests that a tiny percentage of downloaders are willing to contribute to a RAR torrent at all, resulting in soon-dead torrents... with any partial downloads rendered utterly useless.

I have the same gripe about ISOs, NRGs, DAAs, BINs, and other disk image files.  The reality is that unusable file formats repel seeders.  I'm sure that there are lots of people with faster internet connections than mine, but with a 15Mbs down / 5Mbs up fiber optic connection and 24/7 seeding, it's at least a small loss to the torrent community when I am not willing to seed a torrent that I consider valuable.

omgabanana: what do you use PG for? Is it not just another add-on needed only when you don't have a decent firewall?

He0n: tnx!

PG is used for specifically blocking Government/University IP Addresses, Not all firewalls would consider these IP's a threat and so dont auto block them i.e. zonealarm. It is mainly used to stop servers (MPAA/RIAA) from connecting to your machine.
Rar Files do help with torrent distribution because of packet swarming even tho its a chaw unpacking them it helps the superseeder distribute quicker.

@DeltaPan
Either you're unable to read or just being pig headed.  Nobody has ever argued that RAR sucks for reasons of network efficiency.  You're arguing against a point that you must have hallucinated -- nobody ever made a counter-claim.  I am inclined to assume that you're right about your bandwidth utilization claims.

(Although I suspect that you're talking about an inefficiency that's in the single- digit percentages, and trying to make it sound significant... which I'm sure it's not.)

Let me summarize the conversation thus far:

RomanXXII: I prefer AVI files, but I'll download this.

Deltapan: Billions of RAR files are far more efficient for network packets under the BT protocol.  You obviously know nothing about protocols.

Drowlord: Protocol efficiency has nothing to do with why RAR sucks.  RAR files are inconvenient and people don't seed RAR torrents for long.  RAR sucks primarily because it doubles the storage requirement to seed a file.

Deltapan: Disk space has nothing to do with network efficiency, and you obviously don't know anything about mathematics or packets or protocols, because you're disagreeing with me.

Drowlord:  I agree that disk space is unrelated to packet efficiency.  I also agree that packet efficiency has NOTHING TO DO with the issue of RAR files sucking.
